journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Optimization of unknown parameters of adaptive backstepping in position tracking of a permanent magnet linear motor

contrib-group.aff: Laboratory of Intelligent Machines, Lappeenranta University of Technology, Lappeenranta, Finland

author-notes.corresp: *Laboratory of Intelligent Machines, Lappeenranta University of Technology, PO Box 20, FIN-53851, Lappeenranta, Finland. email: heikki.handroos@lut.fi

abstract.p: In the current paper a non-linear load control method is developed and implemented for a permanent magnet linear synchronous motor (PMLSM) with a flexible load. The proposed controller tracks a flexible load to the desired reference position as fast as possible and without awkward oscillation. The control method is based on an adaptive backstepping algorithm whose stability is ensured by the Lyapunov stability theorem. The unknown parameters of the controller were estimated by means of a differential evolution algorithm. The needed states of the system that are used by controller are estimated by using the Kalman filter. The proposed controller is implemented and tested in a linear motor test drive and responses are presented.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Over the past decades, linear motors have been widely used for high-speed and high-accuracy applications, such as precision X–Y tables, fast manipulators, semiconductor manufacturing equipment, computer numerical control (CNC) machine tools, and so on.

Owing to new developments in non-linear control theory, several non-linear control techniques have been introduced in the last two decades. Lu et al. [1] have considered an adaptive method to control a linear motor.

Resonant frequencies of linear motor drives are usually higher than in drives with mechanical transmissions. However, they are often low enough to limit the possible control performance, producing noise or inadmissible oscillations. Zhao et al. [2] have studied an adaptive notch filter with an auto searching function of vibration frequency to reject the mechanical vibration of the linear feeder system with a permanent magnet linear synchronous motor (PMLSM). The notch filter is another widely used filter for vibration suppression [3]. The drawback of the filtering is the low sensitivity to parameter variations; also this method reduces the dynamic properties of the servo system.

Linear state-feedback control theoretically is an attractive method for controlling a linear plant. The method has the property of flexibility of shaping the dynamics of the closed-loop system to meet the desired specification. Motor systems, however, are subjected to parameter variations and load disturbances, which make the system model uncertain and disturbed. In this case, it is difficult to design a classical state-feedback control to satisfy the performance. One possibility to get all of these values is to use an estimator. One example of this kind of control system is presented by Lee and Kim [4], where modified lead-lag control, linear-quadratic (LQ) servo control with a Kalman filter, and fuzzy control methodologies were implemented for active suspension control. Ka and Jie [5] and Yao et al. [6] have used this kind of method successfully in the vibration control of servo systems. Wakui and Fushima [7] have proposed to add positive feedback for suppressing the mechanical vibration.
Robust control is another commonly used method to control the PMLSM where the exact model is not required, and some uncertainty is allowed [8, 9].

The main problem of the previous control methods is that they do not assure global stability of the system due to the high non-linearities in the physical system. If the task of a control system involves large-range and/or high-speed motions, non-linear effects will be significant in the dynamics and a non-linear control may be necessary to achieve the desired performance [10, 11].

The association of the sliding-mode control technique [12, 13] and the backstepping control [14] is an effective approach to synthesize robust control laws for under-actuated non-linear systems with varying parameters. For a certain class of non-linear system a so-called differential flatness can also be used in stabilization [15]. A promising method for non-linear control is the control Lyapunov function (CLF) whose derivative depends on the control and can be made negative by feedback. This is a difficult problem because no general design methods are available. For a large class of systems CLFs can be constructed by backstepping. Backstepping is a recursive design for a system with non-linearities not constrained by linear bounds [11]. The key idea of backstepping is to derive an error equation and to construct a control law and a parameter adjustment law so that the state of the error equation goes to zero [16]. The backstepping method can be successfully implemented for several applications [17].

The system under study in the present paper is a two-mass system connected with a spring. The system has low damping ratio, so it is close to the non-minimum phase systems. The pure two-mass spring system is a non-minimum phase system, which means that all zeros are not in the negative half-plane (two zeros are on the imaginary axis) and the traditional adaptive control methods such as model reference adaptive controllers are not applicable for them [18]. In the proposed adaptive control method, the uncertain plant parameters are estimated online using the adaptive backstepping approach. The estimated parameters are the mass of the load and the spring constant of the system, which can vary in the middle of the working cycle. The adaptive backstepping achieves global stabilization in the presence of unknown parameters.

The proposed controller for position control of the flexible load is based on the study of Hirvonen et al. [19], where the adaptive backstepping was successfully designed and applied to the velocity tracking of a reference model. Because of the increase in number of unknown non-linear parameters of the proposed controller, trial and error is not a suitable method. The unknown non-linear parameters of the proposed controller are calculated by using one of the commonly used optimization methods. These unknown parameters first are estimated by applying a differential evolution (DE) algorithm for sets of offline simulations and then are used for the real-time application.
In this study the so-called observer-based backstepping controller is used. This means that unavailable states for the controller are estimated by an extended Kalman filter (EKF) [20].

The paper is organized as follows. In section 2, the system model is presented. Section 3 outlines the controller design steps. The technical details of applying the current controller, the backstepping method, the differential evolution method, and the state estimation are presented in section 3. Section 4 describes the experimental set-up and section 5 the results for the proposed controller. In section 6 the conclusions are summarized.

sec.title: 2 System Model
sec.p: The modelling of the dynamics of the linear synchronous motor examined in this paper is based on the space-vector theory. The time-varying parameters are eliminated and all of the variables are expressed on orthogonal or mutually decoupled direct and quadrature axes, which move at a synchronous speed of ωs. The d- and q-axis equivalents to the circuit of the PMLSM are shown in Fig. 1, and the corresponding equations are (1) and, (2) respectively.

caption.p: Two-axis model of the linear synchronous motor

The synchronous speed can be expressed as
ω s

v s

, where vs is the linear synchronous velocity, i.e. the velocity with which the motor moves, and τ is the pole pitch, i.e. the length of the pole pair of permanent magnets. Although the physical system does not contain a damper, which in PMLSM usually takes the form of an aluminium cover on the permanent magnets, virtual damping must be included in the model due to eddy currents. The voltage equations of the short-circuited damper winding are
and

where RD and RQ are the d- and q-axis components of the damper winding resistance, and iD and iQ are the d- and q-axis components of the damper winding current. The armature and damper winding flux linkages in equations (1) to (4) are
and

where Lad and Laq are the d- and q-axis components of the armature self-inductance, LD and LQ are the d- and q-axis components of the damper winding inductance, Lmd and Lmq are the d- and q-axis components of the magnetizing inductance, and ψpm is the flux linkage per phase of the permanent magnet. By solving the flux linkage differential equations from (1) to (4) and substituting the current equations from (5) to (8) into these equations, the equations for the simulation model of the linear motor can be derived. The electromagnetic thrust of a PMLSM is
where pe is the electromechanical power and p represents the number of pole pairs. The parameters used in the simulation are introduced in Table 1.

sec.title: 2.1 Non-linearities of PMLSM
sec.p: The force ripple of the PMLSM is larger than that of rotary motors because of the finite length of the stator or mover and the wide slot opening. In the PMLSM, the thrust ripple is caused mainly by the detent force generated between the permanent magnets and the armature. This type of force can be divided into two components: tooth and core-type detent force. The core-type detent force can be efficiently reduced by optimizing the length of the moving part or smooth-forming the edges of the mover and the tooth-type detent force can be reduced by skewing the magnets and chamfering the edges of the teeth [21].

The ripple of the detent force produces both vibration and noise and reduces controllability [22]. The force ripple is dominant at low velocities and accelerations. At higher velocities, the cogging force is relatively small and the influence of dynamic effects (acceleration and deceleration) is more dominant. The force ripple can be described by a sinusoidal function of the load position, x, with a period of φ and an amplitude of Ar
where Ks is a scaling factor. In Fig. 2, the results of the simulation are compared with those measured in the reference system.

caption.p: Comparison of measured and simulated detent forces

sec.p: The model also takes into account the effect of friction. Friction is highly non-linear and may result in steady-state errors, limit cycles, and poor performance. The friction model takes into account the Coulomb (static) and viscous (dynamic) components

where v is the velocity of the motor. The main disadvantage when using highly non-linear models for simulations or control purposes is high discontinuity at near-zero speed, which gives rise to problems such as numerical chatter. The total disturbance force equation can be described using the equations of detent force and friction force; i.e. the disturbance force Fdist is
This resultant disturbance force component is added to the electromotive force to influence the dynamic behaviour of the linear motor system.

The effect of load variation is also taken into consideration. The mechanism in this study is made according to the ACC Benchmark Problem, i.e. a two-mass model. The ACC Benchmark Problem consists of two masses attached by a single spring, moving on a friction-free horizontal surface. Figure 3 shows the real system under study and Fig. 4 demonstrates the schematic diagram of the system. The control input is the force applied to the first mass, and the output is the position or velocity of the second mass.

caption.p: Two-mass and spring model of the system

sec.p: The motion equations of this system are

where k is the spring constant, b is the damping factor, mM and mL are the motor and load masses, FT is the summation of the controller force, F, and the disturbance force, Fdist, xM and xL are motor and load positions, and Δx and
Δ
x ˙
are compression of the spring and the velocity difference between masses, respectively.
Equations (12) and (13) indicate that the non-linearity of the PMLSM originates from the non-linear terms related to the friction and ripple force.

sec.title: 3 Controller Design
sec.p: The state-feedback control assumes that all state variables are available for feedback. In practice, however, not all state variables are measured for feedback and therefore the unavailable state variables must be estimated. In this study a so-called separation principle is used. It allows the output feedback problem to be decomposed into two sub-problems which can be solved separately: the design of a state observer and the design of a state-feedback controller. For non-linear systems the separation principle does not apply, and the design of a state observer is generally coupled with the controller design [11]. However, when the Input-to-State-Stability (ISS) property can be assured for disturbances entering additively to the states in a stabilizing state-feedback law, estimates from a converging state observer can be used in a certainty equivalence approach [23]. In Fig. 4 the separation principle of the system is presented. This section is organized as follows. Section 3.1 introduces the design of the adaptive backstepping controller, where the rates of the plant’s parameters (mM/k and mL/k) are estimated assuming that all system states are available for use in the controller. Section 3.2 introduces the state observer of the system, which assures that the system states of the mechanics needed in the controller are available.

sec.title: 3.1 Adaptive backstepping controller
sec.p:
The backstepping procedure was first introduced by Kokotovic and Arcak [24]. The key idea of backstepping is to start with a system which is stabilizable with a known feedback law for a known Lyapunov function, and then to add to its input an integrator. For the augmented system a new stabilizing feedback law is explicitly designed and shown to be stabilizing for a new Lyapunov function, and so on. The method used in the backstepping controller is called Lyapunov’s direct method. The method, used in the controller, works in such a way that, first, a Lyapunov function V(x) is selected and then a feedback control u(x) that renders
V ˙
(
x , u ( x )
)
a negative definite is sought. With an arbitrary choice of V(x) this attempt may fail, but if V(x) is a CLF, a stabilizing control law u(x) can be found. When V(x) is a CLF, there are many control laws that render
V ˙
(
x , u ( x )
)
a negative definite, and in the study a backstepping method is used.

First system equations are derived and it is assumed that the motor dynamic is negligible, i.e. the dynamics of the mechanism are more dominant. This is due to the fast dynamics of a linear motor relative to a flexible mechanism. In control system design, the mechanism can usually be simplified for a two-mass and spring system, like in Fig. 4, when only the first fundamental natural mode is taken into account.
The motion equations of this system are

sec.title: 3.2 Differential evolution strategy
sec.p: Global optimization methods are under continuous development, and lately genetic algorithms and evolution strategies have been found to be promising stochastic optimization methods [25]. Differential evolution is a simple and powerful population-based, direct-search algorithm for globally optimizing functions defined especially on functions with real-valued parameters. The schematic procedure of a class of differential evolution is as follows [26].
Inputs

where D is the number of parameters, NP is the population size, Fs is the scale factor, CR is the crossover control constant, Gmax is the maximum number of generation, and hi, lo are upper and lower initial parameter bounds, respectively.
Initialize
Here, the number of initial weights is the same as the number of unknown parameters. The initial selected parameters for this strategy are in Table 2.

The cost of the system is considered as a summation of absolute errors for one period (1 s with a 1 ms sampling time), so the cost is a summation of absolute errors for 1000 points. Note that generally the number of the population, NP, is five to ten times the number of parameters, D. Here, the number of NP was set to 60. The results show that differential evolution can find the global minimum cost for the system. Depending on the expected value of the cost, the differential evolution will find the proper weights. The cost of the system is defined as follows
where

The reference velocity xref in equation (56) is the position of the reference model and xload is the estimated position of flexible load. The minimum cost for the system was 28. Figure 5 is the plot of the cost when the differential evolution algorithm is used to search for the global minimum of the unknown parameters. Figure 6 shows the amount of one the controller gain (c3) versus the iterations. It is clear that the gain approaches 87.3 after 30 000 iterations and then remains at the final value. Therefore, the results show that the unknown parameters converge to the specific amounts.

caption.p: Cost of the system versus the number of iterations
The controller gain, c3, versus the number of iterations

sec.title: 3.3 State estimation
sec.p:
Figure 7 demonstrations that the states for the controller were estimated using the Kalman filter. In deriving the Kalman filter equations, the objective is to find an equation that computes a posterior state estimate
x ^
k
as a linear combination of a prior estimate
x ^
k −
and a weighted difference between a measurement yk and a measurement prediction
H
x ^
k −
[27]. The linear difference equations for the discrete Kalman filter are

where Φ, Γ, and H are discretized state, input, and output matrices, respectively, wk is a random process that accounts for the noise present due to mismodelling, and vk is a random noise process accounting for measurement noise.

caption.p: Estimation of states using the Kalman filter

sec.p:
The first step in calculation estimations of the real-time Kalman filter is to initialize the process by suitable conjectures for the estimated state vector
x ^
k
and the estimation error covariance Pk. This procedure is called the time update
The next step is to calculate the Kalman gain and update the state estimation with measurements. This procedure is called the measurement update

where I is an n × n identity matrix. The estimated error covariance Pk is independent of the measurement. It could even be pre-calculated before any measurements are made. This is a direct consequence of the underlying assumption that the noise covariance matrices Q and R might be measured prior to operation of the filter [27, 28].

For the Kalman filter, a linear state-space model of the mechanical system is derived. The friction and other non-linearities are assumed to be system noise, which the Kalman filter handles as a random process. The estimated states of the system are the velocity of the motor vM, the velocity of the load vL, and the spring force Fs, i.e. the state vector is
The state matrix A, input matrix B, and output matrix C are described as

where k is the spring constant. Damping constant b is assumed to be negligible in respect of system dynamics. The control input u in the state-space model is the motor thrust, FT. The process noise covariance Q in this application is
and the measurement covariance R = 0.01 is scalar due to one input for the Kalman filter. Table 3 presents the mechanical parameters in the state-space model.

The acceleration estimation
x ¨
^
L
used in the controller is defined from the estimated spring force
F ^
s
by dividing it by the mass of the load mL, i.e. the acceleration estimation is

sec.title: 4 The Experimental Set-up
sec.p:
The motor studied in the present paper is a commercial three-phase linear synchronous motor application with a rated force of 1675 N. The moving part (the mover) consists of a slotted armature, while the surface permanent magnets are mounted along the whole length of the path (the stator). The permanent magnets are slightly skewed (1.7°) in relation to the normal. Skewing the permanent magnets reduces the detent force [29]. The moving part is set up on an aluminium base with four recirculating roller bearing blocks on steel rails. The position of the linear motor was measured using an optical linear encoder with a resolution of approximately 1
μ
m.

A spring–mass mechanism was built on a tool base in order to act as a flexible load (for example, a picker that increases the level of excitation). The mechanism consists of a moving mass and a break spring, which is connected to a moving mass on the guide.

The physical linear motor application was driven in such a way that the proposed position controller was implemented in Simulink to gain the desired force reference. The derived algorithm was transferred to C code for dSPACE©’s digital signal processor (DSP) to use in real time. The force command, F*, was fed into the drive of the linear motor using a DS1103 input/output card. The computational time step for the position controller was 1 ms, while the current controller cycle was 31.25 µs.

For the Kalman filter introduced in section 3.1, a linear state-space model of the mechanical system was derived. The friction and other non-linearities were assumed to be system noise, which the Kalman filter handles as a random process.

Parameters for the controller are adaptive gains δ and γ, and controller gains c1, c2, c3, and c4 (Table 4). These and other parameters are tuned by the DE method in the control of the non-linear simulation model. In the modelling of a linear motor, a space vector theory is used, and the main non-linearities are taken into consideration. The whole simulation environment was carried out on MATLAB/Simulink software. After testing the control in the simulation model, it was implemented in the physical linear motor application and final tuning was carried out.

sec.title: 5 Results
sec.p: Figures 8 and 9 compare the position tracking responses in the case of a proportional–integral (PI) controller and the proposed load controller. Figure 8 corresponds to the simulation result of the flexible load position tracking by using a PI controller. The performance of this controller is not good and the flexible mechanism starts to vibrate. In Fig. 9 there is a measured position tracking response of the flexible load when the adaptive backstepping is used. The load tracks the reference well and steady-state error is zero; even the system stiffness is relatively loose. In both cases the reference has been a step function, the amplitude of which is 0.1 m and the frequency 0.5 Hz. The measured force of the adaptive backstepping controller is shown in Fig. 10. Figure 11 corresponds to the flexible load tracking by the proposed controller under a sine excitation. The amplitude and frequency of the sine input are the same as step excitation. To get the maximum speed of tracking, the natural frequency of the reference model is chosen to be equal to the first mode the system. Figure 12 shows the Bode plot of the open-loop system. It is clear that the frequency of the first mode is about 55 rad/s, so the maximum natural frequency of the reference model is 55 rad/s.

caption.p: Simulation result from position of the load in the case of PI control
Measured position of the load in the case of a backstepping controller under a step excitation
Measured force in the case of a backstepping controller under a step excitation
Measured position of the load in the case of a backstepping controller under a sine excitation
Bode plot of an open-loop system

sec.p: The dynamics of the adaptation law is tested with the simulation model, which is excited with the step command, the amplitude of which is 0.1 m and the frequency 1 Hz. In the simulation the mass of the load is changed from 2 kg to 5 kg at 10 s, and the spring constant is changed from 13 700 N/m to 6700 N/m at 20 s in the middle of the simulation. Figures 13 and 14 show time-varying estimations of unknown parameters θ1 and θ2 from the previously mentioned simulation, from which it can be perceived how fast the controller adapts to new parameters. The interesting phenomenon in the proposed backstepping controller is that the estimated values are converging, but not to the correct values. This is due to the estimation equations, which are differential functions of the controller states and parameters.

caption.p: The dynamics of the adaptation law in the case of varied load mass and spring constant
The dynamics of the adaptation law in the case of varied load mass and spring constant

sec.p: The motion equation, equation (2), is a simplified form of equation (1) where the cogging and friction forces are affecting the system. These forces and the damping force are neglected in the proposed controller design, so the estimated parameters are converging because of the adaptation law, but the disturbances do affect on the final values. Therefore, the final values are highly dependent on the control parameters. The higher the adaptation gains are, the faster the adaptation dynamics is. On the other hand, too high adaptation gains might make the controller unstable, and therefore the final values are a compromise between the dynamics of the adaptation and response of the system.

sec.title: 6 Conclusions
sec.p: The present study introduces a load control method for a PMLSM and successfully implements it in the physical linear motor application. The motor is controlled by the adaptive backstepping controller. The differential evolution algorithm proved to be an efficient tool for finding unknown non-linear parameters of the controller and estimator. More traditional methods might have a local minimum problem due to their gradient based calculation, i.e. they frequently lead to local optimums. Differential evolution is not based on the gradient method and, therefore, the local minimum problem is avoided. The position and velocity of the load and the velocity of the motor for the controller are estimated using the Kalman filter. As shown, the performance of the PI controller is poor at tracking the reference model. The cogging and friction forces are considered as disturbances, so the estimated parameters are converging, but because of the disturbance they do not approach to the final values. The vibration of the load is removed and the proposed controller is perceived to be stable in all conditions. The system model for the Kalman filter can be described by using a transient or frequency response to define offline mass and load states.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not for profit sectors.
